div1.p:
223 West Lanvale Street.
Baltimore, Maryland,
February 10, 1905.
In accordance with the wish of His Excellency, Baron Moncheur, Belgian Minister at Washington, I have the honor of calling your attention to the enclosed documents.

Among them you will find a copy of the Memorial of the Congo question presented to Congress by Senator Cullom on behalf of the Belgian Protective Association of America. The object of the Memorial is to refute the charge brought against the Administration of the Congo Free State and the Government of His Majesty, King Leopold II, by certain Missionary Organizations inspired partly by discontented missionaries but chiefly by rubber merchants of Liverpool.

The other document which I hand you is a form of Petition endorsing the above mentioned Memorial, and it is desired that you will endeavor to secure for it the largest possible number of signatures of influential persons, both Belgians and American business men.

There has been recently formed in New York by a number of well known men, a society called the Belgian Protective Association of America, and you will find enclosed a short memorandum stating the objects of the organization, its by-laws, and the names of a few of its prominent members. About 200 members have been already enrolled in New York. It is contemplated to make this organization permanent so as to be available, not only in the present of circumstances, but also in the future, for the cultivation of friendly and commercial relations between the United States, on the one hand, and Belgium and the Congo Free State, on the other. I request that you will be kind enough to form a branch of the Belgian Protective Association in your Consular district, and that you will return me the Petition with the signatures of your member properly affixed, and also that you will forward a list of the membership of your branch to the Secretary of the Belgian Protective Association, 83 Worth Street, New York City.

For obvious reasons it is thought desirable that His Majesty's
Consuls should not appear too conspicuously in the organization and for this reason it would be well, wherever practicable, to select as the active officers of the Branch prominent business men not connected with His Majesty's Service.

I suggest that, if possible, you induce some of your influential friends to write personal letters to their Senators and Representatives endorsing the Memorial and the Petition of the Belgian Protective Association.
I avail myself of this opportunity to thank you on behalf of Baron Moncheur, as well as on my own account, for the interest you have taken in the defense of His Majesty's Government in the Congo, and

With high appreciation of your courtesy,
I remain,
Yours faithfully,
James Gustavus Whiteley
Consul for the Congo Free State.
